summary: The mutual-fund industry will lose its biggest fan of  Berkshire Hathaway  with the retirement of Fidelity Contrafund manager Will Danoff at the end of 2026 after 35 years at its helm. Contrafund’s stake in Berkshire is now worth about $10 billion, Barron’s calculates.

headline: Tech stocks strong but earnings may add volatility, says market expert

"So I wouldn't be too worried about the S&P 500 going up." She adds that Amazon is one company that will be closely watched this earnings season."If we don't hear of something, good news with regards to AI, especially in their cloud infrastructure, I think there may be some disappointment," she said.

headline: UPS looks to cut up to 30,000 jobs this year
summary: UPS is planning to cut up to 30,000 operational jobs this year as the package delivery company continues with its turnaround efforts and reducing the number of Amazon shipments that it handles.  Chief Financial Officer Brian Dykes said during the company's conference call on Tuesday that the job cuts will be made through a voluntary buyout offer for full-time drivers and through attrition.  UPS said in a regulatory filing in October that it had cut about 34,000 operational positions and closed daily operations at 93 leased and owned buildings during the first nine months of last year.

headline: Amazon Is Closing Its Fresh Grocery, Go Convenience Stores
summary: Amazon Fresh and Amazon Go stores will close, the company said in a blog post on Tuesday, with some locations converted into Whole Foods Market stores.  “While we’ve seen encouraging signals in our Amazon-branded physical grocery stores, we haven’t yet created a truly distinctive customer experience with the right economic model needed for large-scale expansion,” Amazon said.  Since the surprise opening of a physical bookstore in 2015, Amazon has tried and failed to establish a foothold under its own brand in categories from groceries to fashion, often with technological flourishes such as digital price tags or novel checkout methods.

headline: Pinterest will lay off 15% of its workforce as the platform pivots resources to AI
summary: Pinterest plans to lay off under 15% of its workforce, as part of broader restructuring that arrives as the image-sharing platform pivots more of its money to artificial intelligence.  In a Tuesday securities filing, San Francisco-based Pinterest said it was making these cuts to support “transformation initiatives” — which include reallocating the company's resources to AI-focused roles and prioritizing AI-powered products.  Beyond the coming layoffs, Pinterest said it will reduce office space.

The company operates 57 Amazon Fresh stores and 15 Amazon Go stores.

headline: Big Tech earnings to test AI rally as resurgent Alphabet takes lead
summary: STORY: Microsoft and Meta will kick off Big Tech earnings this week under pressure to prove their costly bets on AI can power another year of strong growth.That's as a resurgent Alphabet takes the lead in the high-stakes race.The companies, along with Amazon, are expected to lift their AI spending this year by 30% to more than $500 billion.It's an unprecedented outlay that will sharpen investor scrutiny.Some have expressed doubts over whether Microsoft squandered a first-mover advantage in AI it secured through its OpenAI investment.Meta too is under pressure to show payoffs from its expensive push into superintelligence.Both stocks declined more than 6% in the last three months of 2025.While Amazon saw a small 5% gain after its November deal with OpenAI signaled that the largest cloud-computing provider in the U.S. was no longer behind on AI.Alphabet shares though surged about 29% in that period.It followed a strong reception of Google's latest Gemini 3 model.The company also recently struck a deal to power Apple's revamped Siri.LSEG data showed that in the October-December quarter, Google Cloud revenue growth likely quickened to 35% from 33.5% in the previous three months.But doubts linger about the real-world benefits for the businesses adopting the technology.And feeding into bubble fears that hounded the technology industry for much of last year.

headline: Meta signs deal to pay Corning up to $6 billion for fiber-optic cables, CNBC reports
summary: Facebook parent Meta Platforms has signed a deal to pay Gorilla Glass maker Corning up to $6 ​billion through 2030 for fiber-optic cables in its AI ‌data centers, CNBC reported on Tuesday.  The company expects AI hyperscalers, including Meta, Amazon, ‌Alphabet's Google and Microsoft, to be its biggest customers next year, the report said, citing an interview with Corning CEO Wendell Weeks.  Corning's optical connectivity products are among key components required to support the ⁠massive computing and data ‌transmission demands at data centers.

headline: How 175-year-old glass company Corning won a $6 billion AI infrastructure deal with Meta
summary: Meta is giving Corning up to $6 billion for fiber-optic cable in its AI data centers, in a deal reported first by CNBC. Famous for making iPhone glass for Apple, the 175-year-old U.S. company is now seeing record fiber demand and its stock rose 75% in a year. CNBC went to North Carolina for an exclusive interview with Corning CEO Wendell Weeks about a new type of optical fiber invented for AI, and saw the expansion that Corning says will make its Hickory cable factory the largest in the world.
